title: Why James Milner chose to join Liverpool after leaving Man City
text:

Brendan Rodgers has revealed it was James Milner's desire to win the Champions League which persuaded him to join Liverpool.

The Reds midfielder moved to Anfield on a free transfer in 2015 after Man City decided against renewing his contract.

Milner had offers from elsewhere, with Arsenal rumoured to be interested, but he signed for Liverpool after Rodgers persuaded him on a move.

Rodgers told the Echo : "It’s really, really interesting because he wanted to come to Liverpool. He had won the Premier League, he had won cups. His whole ambition was to win the Champions League and he felt that he would have a better opportunity to win it at Liverpool."

(Image: REUTERS)

The decision is perhaps surprising, given that at the time it had been a decade since Liverpool last won the Champions League, and they'd been knocked out of the competition at the group stages the season before.

Liverpool also suffered a dismal campaign in the league, finishing sixth, despite challenging for the title the year previous.

Rodgers was then relived of his duties at the club in October of that year, just months after Milner had signed.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

But Milner's decision was justified when Rodgers' successor Jurgen Klopp led the team to European glory in June, with the veteran playing a pivotal role in the triumph.

"When we got the call to say he was going to come, I was so happy," Rodgers said. "His professionalism, his intensity, his focus. It was always going to help the squad.

"Even though it was only a short time we worked together, he was always going to be a really good signing.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

“He was brilliant. Then you see what he has done. He has played at left-back, he has played in midfield. He is just a top class professional and he has done absolutely brilliant for the club."

His old manager was on the receiving end of Milner's talents on Saturday though, as he showed nerves of steel to tuck away a last-minute penalty to earn Liverpool a crucial win over Rodgers' Leicester .

The Reds now top the table with maximum points from eight games, and an eight-point lead over Milner's old club Man City.
